channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for IN
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for IN

item.title: Report X-2024070045
item.description:
Report X-2024070045

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-03T15:13:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-26
  • City: INDIANAPOLIS
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On june 25th a box marked as UN1266 Perfumery Products was found damaged and leaking. it is unknown how the damage to the box occurred however 3 bottles inside of the package were broken and leaked their contents. The package was placed into a salvage drum and the shipper contacted for an amended shippers dec and further disposition.

item.title: Report E-2024070003
item.description:
Report E-2024070003

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-03T15:13:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-19
  • City: EDINBURGH
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On June 19, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of sodium hydroxide was damaged in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Indiana Spill Response (ISR) to remediate the impacted site. ISR personnel deployed granular absorbents and a neutralizing agent to remediate the site. All spent absorbents and debris were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. The damaged containers of product were placed into one (1) 85-gallon drum for disposal.
